  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab. This course carries GE credit but is intended for a specific group of students rather than a general student audience. It is part of the curriculum for majors and pre-professional students. Sections 13192 and 13195 are "SEA PHAGES" Genomics research sections. Sections 13191, 13193 and 19194 are Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE) sections. Enrollment in this course is limited to students admitted into the Freshman Science Honors (FSH) program.

CRS_DESC: Exploration of the unique properties of brain cells that allow complex perceptions and behaviors; examination of structure and activity of brain cells that underlie function.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: Experience in basic techniques through supervised research in the research laboratory of a departmental faculty member.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (BISC 120 or BISC 121) and (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and (CHEM 105B or CHEM 108 or CHEM 115B)
CRS_NOTE: • Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 120 or BISC 121) and 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and 1 from (CHEM 105B or CHEM 108 or CHEM 115B)

CRS_DESC: Physiological functions of the circulatory, digestive, endocrine, integuementary, musculoskeletal, nervous, respiratory, and urogenital systems in animals. Lecture, 3 hours; Laboratory, 3 hours.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221)
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: Introduction to general statistical theory with higher-level mathematics for biological data analysis. Basic programming in R. Discussion of techniques to describe, visualize and model different types of data.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the QBIO department but may qualify for major credit in BISC. To register, enroll in QBIO 310.

CRS_DESC: Structure and function of biological macromolecules; major metabolic pathways including glycolysis and photosynthesis. DNA replication, repair, and recombination; gene expression, regulation and epigenetics.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Not available for major credit. Final exam date: Tues. May 07, 4:30-6:30 p.m.

CRS_DESC: History of evolutionary thought; molecular basis for evolution; dynamics of genes in populations; specialization and macroevolution; patterns of evolution. Recommended preparation: BISC-320, BISC-325, and familiarity with algebra, basic chemistry, and basic physics.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and (BISC 120 or BISC 121)
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221) and 1 from (BISC 120 or BISC 121)
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: Builds upon a basic science background to provide students with an awareness of cutting edge scientific research, its technological applications and its societal ramifications.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (BISC 120 or BISC 121 or BISC 220 or BISC 221) and (CHEM 105A or CHEM 107 or CHEM 115A) and (PHYS 135A or PHYS 151)
CRS_NOTE: • Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 120 or BISC 121 or BISC 220 or BISC 221) and 1 from (CHEM 105A or CHEM 107 or CHEM 115A) and 1 from (PHYS 135A or PHYS 151)

CRS_DESC: Basic biochemical principles; classes of molecules - structure and function; cellular energetics.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (CHEM 322A or CHEM 325A)
  • Note: Register for lecture, one lab and the quiz section. Final exam date: Tues. May 07, 4:30-6:30 p.m.

CRS_DESC: Exploration of environmentally transmitted human diseases; understanding the human/pathogen/environment nexus that leads to disease in human populations; disease transmission reduction.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 103 or BISC 120)
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the ENST department but may qualify for major credit in BISC. To register, enroll in ENST 335.

CRS_DESC: Introduction to the morphology, classification, distribution and physiology of mammals; study of major mammalian groups worldwide and identification and field study of local species.
Introduction to the experiments, theories and knowledge of modern cell biology; analysis of cutting-edge research papers; focused on organelles, signaling, cytoskeleton and the cell cycle.

CRS_NAME: Introduction to Computational Analysis of Biological Data
CRS_DESC: A project-based course integrating biology, computer science, and statistics through the analysis of genomic datasets available publicly or collected and sequenced during the semester.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the QBIO department but may qualify for major credit in BISC. To register, enroll in QBIO 401.

CRS_DESC: Fundamental concepts of RNA biology and state-of-the-art biotechnologies using RNA for medical and industrial applications; CRISPR/Cas genome editing; therapeutic advances exploiting RNA biology.

Introduction to community ecology, macroecology, biodiversity and ecosystem functions, and current debates on trends in biodiversity; concepts include ecological theory, modeling, data management and analysis.

An examination of individual nerve cell development, target location, and establishment of functional synapses; how dysfunction in these processes contributes to neurological and neuropsychiatric diseases.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: BISC 421
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion.

CRS_DESC: Sensory and motor systems to illustrate concepts regarding the functional organization of the brain, from microcircuitry of neural circuits to global processes such as perception. Prerequisite: BISC 421.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: BISC 421
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion.

CRS_NAME: Applications of Molecular Biology to Medicine
CRS_DESC: Advances and trends in the understanding, diagnosis and treatment of human diseases.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 312 or BISC 330 or CHEM 350)
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Senior

CRS_DESC: Examination of various neurological disorders originating from developmental signaling and/or anatomical abnormalities.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: BISC 421
  • Note: This course requires instructor permission to enroll.

CRS_DESC: How the parts of the brain are interconnected to form a complex biological computer, from historical, evolutionary and developmental perspectives.
Literature-based seminar in current and classical topics in genetics.
In-depth study of the role of the immune system in oncogenesis. Discussion of cellular transformation, immune surveillance, immune-based therapies, and new approaches in cancer treatment.
Introduction to the habitat, phylogenetic, physiological and metabolic diversity of microbial life in aquatic environments.
Macromolecular structure and function; enzymology; metabolic regulation. Lecture, 3 hours; discussion, 2 hours.
Consideration of the biological and social-cultural factors that govern the evolution of life spans and the life of humans and selected animal models. Recommended preparation: statistics
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 120 or BISC 121)
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the GERO department but may qualify for major credit in BISC. To register, enroll in GERO 440.

CRS_DESC: Evolution and comparative anatomy of vertebrates.

Fundamentals of protein engineering and its biotechnological applications in medicine, chemical processes and energy; methods for engineering biological molecules and designing protein engineering strategies.

CRS_NAME: Methods in Marine Biology and Biological Oceanography
CRS_DESC: Introduction to standard methods used in oceanography and marine biology through a a combination of lectures, laboratory exercises and field experiences.

CRS_NAME: Seminar in Molecular and Computational Biology
CRS_DESC: Topical seminar in molecular and computational biology. Junior, senior or graduate standing.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior, Master Student, Doctoral Student

CRS_DESC: Topical seminar in neurobiology.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior, Master Student, Doctoral Student
  • Note: This course requires instructor permission to enroll.

CRS_DESC: Exploration of the complex interactions between the nervous and immune systems, and disorders encompassing both neuroscience and immunology. Topics include autoimmunity, cancer, neurodevelopment, neuroimmunological treatments.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (BISC 120 or BISC 121) and (BISC 220 or BISC 221)
CRS_NOTE: • Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 120 or BISC 121) and 1 from (BISC 220 or BISC 221)

CRS_DESC: Oceanography and marine biology, sampling techniques, evolutionary adaptations, morphology, systematics.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 103 or BISC 120 or BISC 121)
  • Note: This class includes a mandatory weekend field trip to Catalina Island on February 9-11, 2024. The chartered boat will leave at 2pm from the Port of Los Angeles Feb. 9 and will return to the Port at 3:30 pm Feb. 11. Transportation will be provided to and from the Port. There are no charges for this field trip. Students that have a perceived conflict with this field trip must contact the faculty prior to registration.

CRS_DESC: Instruction in basic concepts and evolutionary mechanisms of animal and human development. Emphasis on molecular, genetic and cellular processes underlying vertebrate and invertebrate development.
Foundational skill-building for modeling and analysis of biological data. Hands-on instruction for developing and simulating models of dynamic biological systems.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the QBIO department but may qualify for major credit in BISC. To register, enroll in QBIO 482.

CRS_DESC: Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Enrollment in this course requires an application available at dornsife.usc.edu/bisc/bisc-undergraduate-forms/

CRS_DESC: Directed research focused on sustainable marine aquaculture; in particular, research and development projects leveraged by a partnership between academic, non-profit and commercial organizations.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (BISC 103 or BISC 120 or BISC 121)
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Master Student, Senior, Senior (fifth year)

CRS_DESC: Not available for graduate credit.

CRS_DESC: Not available for graduate credit.

CRS_DESC: Current genetic and biochemical analysis of replication, recombination, mutagenesis, and repair. Fundamentals of transcription and regulation of gene expression. Recent applications of genetic engineering and genome analysis.

CRS_DESC: Rotation of graduate students through molecular biology research laboratories to learn the major technological skills required in the field. Graded CR/NC.
A basic grounding in broad aspects of the neuroscience of hearing and vocal communication.

CRS_NAME: Advanced Seminar in Molecular and Microbial Ecology
CRS_DESC: Microorganisms dominate biological processes in the ocean. These species pose significant problems for estimating species diversity, abundance and activity. Examination of modern molecular biological approaches for analyzing aquatic microbial communities and their ecological roles.

CRS_DESC: Evolutionary patterns and processes in the marine environment, with an emphasis on adaptation to environmental change.
Advanced training for molecular biology graduate students in reading primary journal articles. Emphasis on critical analyses of primary scientific literature.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Computational Biology and Bioinformatics, Computational Molecular Biology, Molecular Biology
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student, Master Student

CRS_DESC: Current topics in integrative and evolutionary biology.
Multi-instructor course designed to introduce students to the breadth and depth of faculty interests within the MEB Section of Biological Sciences and the Natural History Museum.
Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CRS_DESC: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching within College disciplines. Intended for teaching assistants in Dornsife College.

• Prerequisite: PHYS 152
  • Note: Register for lecture and discussion

CRS_DESC: Principles of physical chemistry relevant for the life sciences: thermodynamics, chemical equilibria, molecular dynamics, kinetics, molecular structures and interactions, spectroscopy, statistical thermodynamics and macromolecular structures. Duplicates credit in CHEM 430a.

A survey of representative groups of widely used synthetic organic reactions; emphasis on scope, limitations, and stereochemical consequences.
Theoretical and experimental methods of molecular spectroscopy and applications to chemistry. Rotational, vibrational, electronic, electron and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopies.

CRS_NAME: Gender and Sexuality in Literary Theory
CRS_DESC: Literary representations and theories of gender difference. Examines questions of gendered voice in writing and the cultural construction of gender in various periods and cultures.

CRS_NAME: Zen and Daoism in Asian Literature
CRS_DESC: Studies of the presence and influence of Zen Buddhism and Daoism in Asian literature, with a focus on China and Japan.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Examination of literary and autobiographical texts that raise questions of justice in multicultural societies; links to theories of justice in historical, political, or philosophical contexts.

CRS_NAME: Europe and the Writing of Others
CRS_DESC: Analysis of European texts -- literary, musical, philosophical, visual -- that focus on other cultures, as well as of non-European texts dealing with Europe or European cultural forms.
Analysis of the Divina Commedia and other works. Conducted in English. (Duplicates credit in former ITAL 450)
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the ITAL department but may qualify for major credit in COLT. To register, enroll in ITAL 382.

CRS_DESC: The reciprocal, ideological relations between modes of listening, sounds, music; and literature, film, culture. Examines a range of issues in auditory culture across a broad historical span.
Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

CRS_DESC: Critical readings of a series of texts in the liberal arts designed to promote discussion of important themes, theoretical approaches, research directions, and interdisciplinary connections. Graded CR/NC.
Modern tools of cultural and discursive analysis which seek to demystify "the natural," as it appears in the formation of cultures, their institutions, and individuals.
A guided polymathic inquiry into Los Angeles as fact and imaginative creation, featuring in-depth student research and projects.

CRS_DESC: Theories and practices in university-level teaching of close-reading and analytical writing, using texts central to Western tradition. Graduate student professionalization throught topical workshops and discussions. Open to assistant lecturers and teaching assistants only. Graded CR/NC.

CRS_DESC: This course introduces students to the origin of the basic components of Chinese scripts and the basic principles and styles of calligraphy.

• Prerequisite: EALC 103A
  • Note: After week one of classes, registration for this course requires instructor approval. Check "Exceptions" in the Final Exam Schedule for the final exam date.

CRS_DESC: The sound system of modern Chinese; aural comprehension, oral expression, basic patterns, and writing system.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: D-clearance for Chinese I is available at language.usc.edu. After Week one of classes, registration for this course requires instructor approval. Check "Exceptions" in the Final Exam Schedule for final exam date.

CRS_DESC: Dialogue practice and conversation; reading of simple stories and essays; comparison of Chinese and English grammar; writing of paragraphs.

CRS_DESC: The basics of reading and writing modern Chinese; intensive reading and writing of paragraphs, essays and stories; extensive reading of beginner-level authentic materials.
Basic Korean conversation practice, aural comprehension, basic grammar and building proficiency of reading and writing with Hangul (Korean alphabet).

CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_NAME: Introduction to Chinese Culture, Art and Literature
CRS_DESC: Introduction to the civlization, art and literature of pre-modern China through the lens of the cultural products of identity.

CRS_DESC: Furthers students' knowledge in the Chinese writing system and develops students' skills in a more advanced calligraphy style.

Continuation of EALC 220. More sophisticated grammar and vocabulary for natural conversation. Enhancing fundamental reading and writing skills, expanding the knowledge of kanji.

Continuation of EALC 320. Improve and strengthen abilities to speak, listen, read and write, coping with more involved materials and situation.
Japanese literature from the earliest times to the present; development of prose, poetry and the novel; evolution of theatre; Japanese literature under Western influence. Conducted in English.

CRS_DESC: Combined classroom discussion and supervised internship at companies. Practical experience in applying communication and cultural knowledge in a professional, "real world" employment context.

Continuation of EALC 412a.

CRS_NAME: Free People, Free Thought and Free Markets
CRS_DESC: The philosophical foundations of modern political and economic thought, including economic rationality, neoclassical economics, free-market vs. socialist economies and behavioral economics.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the PHIL department but may qualify for major credit in ECON. To register, enroll in PHIL 101.

CRS_DESC: Behavior of firms and consumers, functions of the price system, competition and monopoly, labor markets, poverty, government regulation, international trade, and the environment.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_DESC: Unemployment, inflation and output determination and links.Effects of government taxation and spending on growth, investment,saving, consumption, and trade.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_DESC: Decision-making by business firms, consumer preferences and behavior, uncertainty, competition, monopoly, labor and resource markets, efficient resource allocation, externalities, and government policy.
The determinants of aggregate income, employment, and inflation;economic fluctuations; fiscal and monetary policy; financialmarkets; the national debt.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (ECON 203 and ECON 205) and (MATH 118 or MATH 125)

CRS_DESC: Introduction to statistical methods appropriate for analyzing economic data: probability theory, random variables and probability distributions, sampling, estimation, statistical inference.
Application of statistical methods to economic data: estimating economic relationships using regression analysis, testing hypotheses involving economic behavior, forecasting economic variables.
Analyze varied industries using legal, business, and economic principles. Emphasis is on how these forces shape marketing strategies.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (ECON 203 or ECON 351 or BUAD 351)
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the MKT department but may qualify for major credit in ECON. To register, enroll in MKT 333.

CRS_DESC: Causes of economic underdevelopment: historical, institutional, structural, ideological, technological, cultural. Patterns and theories of development. Role of government, international trade, and education in economic growth.

Development and business applications of: theory of the firm; theory of the consumer; inter-temporaldecisions; decisions under risk; market failures; industrial and enterprise structure. Prerequisites: MATH 118 or MATH 125 or MATH 126 or MATH 226. Not for major credit for: Economics, Economics/Mathematics, Social Sciences (Economics). Duplicates credit in BUAD 351.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (MATH 118 or MATH 125 or MATH 126 or MATH 226)

CRS_DESC: Theoretical development and significance to business and markets of economic growth; inflation;unemployment; monetary and fiscal policy; business cycles; savings and investment; exchange rates. Corequisite: ECON 351. Recommended preparation: introductory economics course, high school math, and algebra. Not for major credit for: Economics, Economics/Mathematics, Social Sciences (Economics). Duplicates credit in BUAD 352.
The money, bond, stock, and other financial markets; portfolio choice; determinants of asset prices and interest rates; inflation; interactions between financial markets and government policies.

The challenges of policy coordination among independent political entities, starting from the aftermath of German unification (and the ramifications it had in a fixed exchange rate system) to the recent national debt crisis that followed the great recession.

Analysis of strategic economic interactions. Topics include bargaining, insurance, patents, voting, environment depletion, strategic trade, learning, reputation, strikes, corporate takeovers, and the provision of public goods.
Detailed discussion of economic models, including models of health, addiction, demand for healthcare and demand for insurance.
Examination of the traditional and behavioral theories of decision-making and the state of the art in the field. Prerequisite: ECON 303.
Common law and property; rationing of justice; resource allocation between prevention and enforcement; division of decision making between public and private sectors.
Factors that make values an essential feature of human society; how values develop, change and are abandoned; role of values in economic development.
Determinants and economic consequences of international trade patterns; effects of trade restrictions and trading blocs; trade negotiations and arrangements.

General equilibrium analysis of economics with financial markets; decision making under uncertainty; methods of risk reduction; portfolio theory and valuation of securities; efficiency of security markets.
Fundamental principles in designing successful market mechanisms to allocate resources.

CRS_NAME: Economic Consulting and Applied Managerial Economics
CRS_DESC: Economic consulting and managerial economic methods applied in real world problems. Economic methods to analyze issues of intellectual property, environmental damage, trademark infringement, brand value, and consumer demand.
Pricing and resource allocation in imperfectly competitive markets; monopoly regulation, collusion, cartels, mergers and antitrust; patents and development incentives; industry case studies.
Supervised individual research. Not available for graduate credit. Requires departmental approval.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_DESC: Individual research supervised by a faculty advisor. Successful completion required for departmental honors degree.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for lecture and discussion

CRS_DESC: Selected topics in economic theory, history, or policy.
Theories of the household and the firm; product and factor markets; perfect and imperfect competition; welfare criteria.
Theories of aggregate economic activity; design and use of macroeconometric models; stabilization and control of inflation, unemployment, and growth.

CRS_NAME: Game Theory with Economic and Financial Applications
CRS_DESC: Applying game theory to economic and financial markets and interactions in a diverse set of examples like reputation, herding, bubbles and crashes, auctions, strategic information revelation and information accumulation in markets. Witnessing the wide range of applications that is amenable to game theoretical analysis.
Application of econometric tools using standard econometric software packages for microcomputers; empirical applications to selected economic problems of estimation and inference.

Understanding and implementing models commonly used in time series econometrics. Emphasis is placed on intuition and application. Assists students understanding how to use time series data to test hypotheses and serve as an introduction to the ideas and techniques of forecasting.
Classical economic theory; its precursors, main contributors, extensions and critics; focus upon the writings and ideas of Smith, Say, Malthus, Ricardo, Mill and Marx.

Development, underdevelopment and the problems thereof; agriculture, industry, trade, population, human capital, capital formation; structural, technological, environmental and institutional changes; political economy of the state.
Introduction and exploration of quantitative methods and data sources used for applied trade policy analysis.
Introduction to the theory and practice of causal econometrics in modern settings of large-scale data. Major algorithms from machine learning focused on methodology and applications.
Introduces the novel business model and important features associated with digital platforms and analyzes firms various competitive behavior and anticompetitive conducts in the digital space.
Efficiency, market failure, government regulation, some basics for antitrust economics, competition policy analysis and collusion and agreements among competitors.
Economic methods to analyze issues of intellectual property, environmental damage, trademark infringement, brand value and consumer demand, using an applied econometric approach.
The role of designing incentives to reduce negative urban externalities and the interplay between spatial Big Data and testing urban economics hypotheses.
Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

Part-time or full-time, practical work experience in the student's field of study. Students must have a specific job/internship offer. Job must be related to students major. The internship must be located at an off-campus facility. Students are individually supervised by faculty. Students must have been in F-1 student status for at least one academic year in a degree-seeking program before they can apply for CPT, with a cumulative 3.0 GPA. Course does not apply to degree credit. Open only to graduate students.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student, Master Student

CRS_DESC: General equilibrium theory; existence, uniqueness, and stability; welfare economics; social choice; dynamic models and uncertainty; special topics. Prerequisite: ECON-601.

Macroeconomic theory based on the concepts of optimal growth and intertemporal equilibrium; overlapping generations models; recent developments in macroeconomic theory. Prerequisites: ECON-601 and ECON-602.
Examination of behavioral theories used to describe and predict choices made in both an individual decision-making setting and strategic environments.

Review of statistical methods of estimation and inference, linear regression with multicollinearity and serial correlation; multivariate regression and simultaneous equations. Prerequisite: ECON 611. Duplicates credit in former ECON 511.
Use of quantitative models to describe and forecast economic activity; estimation and application of such models to selected policy problems. Prerequisites: ECON 609.
Experimental methods relying on non-choice data. Design methods of experiments that record information in decision-making and physiological data of emotions.
The functions of laws, rules, customs, conventions, and other restrictions on economic and social activity. Theories of institutional evolution. Prerequisites: ECON-500 or ECON-601.

Theory and empirics of the sources of and barriers to economic development and the micro underpinnings of macroeconomic dynamics of growth, inequality, and productivity. Prerequisites: ECON 601 and ECON 609.
Current areas of research in macroeconomics: Structural Change; Inequality and Macroeconomics.
Think about and design empirical studies in economics using cutting-edge approaches to causal inference -- structural and discrete choice models, micro-macro models and historical data models.

Econometric analysis of industrial organization issues including industry regulation and deregulation, collusions and pricing in differentiated oligopolistic markets, entry and exit, auction mechanisms, contractual relationships. Prerequisites: ECON-601 and ECON-603. Recommended preparation: ECON 600, ECON 603, ECON 612, ECON 615, ECON 680.
Current research in economic theory presented by faculty, students, and outside scholars. Graded CR/NC.
Current research in econometrics presented by faculty, students, and outside scholars. Graded CR/NC.
Current research in international, regional, and urban development economics presented by faculty, students, and outside scholars. Graded CR/NC.

Topics in dynamic economics involving business fluctuations, economic growth and development, microeconomic adjustments and market mechanisms; related quantitative and qualitative methods; empirical research involving economic change. Graded CR/NC.
Presentations on current research in empirical microeconomics by outstanding scholars from leading Economics departments and faculty at USC. Open only to Economics Ph.D. students. Graded CR/NC.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Economics
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student

CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Close study of Shakespeare's plays and poems to introduce his language, stagecraft, literary "genius," social and literary contexts, precursors and rivals, and legacy.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Introduction to theory and practice of literary study.

CRS_DESC: Intensive reading of major writers to 1800.

CRS_DESC: Intensive reading of major writers, 18001950.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Intensive reading of representative writers.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Introduction to major forms, styles and theories of narrative, with attention to characterization, plot, genres, ethics, empathy, perspective, audience and social conditions.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Study of literary modes of narrative and their uses in medical understanding, character formation, social identity, and relations between mind and body.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_NAME: Introduction to the Genre of Nonfiction
CRS_DESC: Study of forms of nonfiction writing, focusing on craft and process: how it works and how to read, write and write about it.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_NAME: Introduction to the Genre of Poetry
CRS_DESC: Historical survey of the traditions of lyric poetry from Shakespeare to the contemporary, examining the genre's multiple forms of literary, visual, and aural expression.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Introduction to the techniques and practice of writing narrative in fiction and literary non-fiction
Introduction to the techniques and practice of writing prose fiction.
Introduction to the techniques and practice of writing poetry.
A study of literature and literary theory through the themes and theories of wonder, magic and the uncanny in English literature before 1800.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_NAME: Women in English and American Literature after 1800
CRS_DESC: Women as writers and as subjects, with special emphasis on feminist and liberationist traditions and on changing female images after 1800.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Questions of gay and lesbian identity, expression and experience in a variety of literary and cultural forms; emphasis on sexual politics, equality and difference.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Diversity: This course satisfies the university's diversity requirement.

CRS_NAME: Periods and Genres in American Literature
CRS_DESC: A concentrated reading and criticism of the works of one period or one genre of American literature; for example, colonial literature, the American Renaissance, American poetry, American drama.
Literary travel using novels to explore regional culture and unify the study of literature, history, geography, politics and social studies.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Study of poetry written in English since 1945, with special emphasis on the last two decades.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Selected British, Irish, and American drama from the post World War II period (1945 to the present).
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Literary studies in the relationship between fiction and drama and their adaptation as films.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: An examination of how literature and related arts intersect in a particular cultural milieu. Selected topics.
Investigation of the scope and possibilities of British and American science fiction as a genre, with some attention to its historical development.
Course in the theory and practices of "popular culture," highlighting modern and comtemporary culture, film, video and popular music, as well as narrative forms.
Intermediate practical workshop concentrating on the creation of narrative in fiction and literary nonfiction.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (ENGL 302 or ENGL 305)
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Narrative Studies

CRS_DESC: Apprenticeship with experienced writer-teachers, providing students with a pedagogical framework and practical experience for teaching creative writing in schools and community settings.
A practical course in composition of prose fiction.
A practical course in poetry writing.
Prerequisite: English 405 and/or consent of instructor.
Prerequisite: Acceptance of manuscript by instructor.

CRS_NAME: English Literature of the Middle Ages
CRS_DESC: Selected studies in the major figures, genres, and themes of Middle English literature to Malory, with special emphasis on Chaucer.
Major history plays, comedies, and tragedies.
American poetry, fiction, and drama since World War I with special attention to Eliot, Frost, Hemingway, Fitzgerald, O'Neill, Stevens, Faulkner, and Nabokov.

Development of the poetry, essay, short story and novel of the Chicano and Latino peoples of the United States, with particular emphasis on the differentiating characteristics between the multiple cultures that constitute the Latino populations.

• Diversity: This course satisfies the university's diversity requirement.

CRS_DESC: Representative plays, especially those of the Elizabethan, Jacobean, and Restoration periods.
Theory and practice of fiction in works of major writers such as Austen, Dickens, Thackeray, George Eliot, Meredith, and Hardy.

CRS_DESC: Selected problems in literary history and criticism.

  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Senior

CRS_DESC: Seminar in workshop form to accompany completion of Senior HonorsThesis. Bi-weekly meetings to complete thesis according to contract.

CRS_NAME: Literatures and Cultures of the Romantic Period
CRS_DESC: Studies in British literature and culture, from the 1790s to 1830s, including gender and genre, authorship and authenticity, "romance" and revolution, forms of belief and doubt, and other topics.

Plays for the stage shall be written using public-domain poetry and prose as inspiration and source material, complemented with exploring poetry, prose, and varied dramas as context for the student writer. Students should be well-versed in literature, and have written in one or more genres.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the THTR department but may qualify for major credit in ENGL. To register, enroll in THTR 501.

CRS_DESC: Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
Studies in rural and urban fictions, modernism, the shift from imagism and symbolism to confessional poetry, recovered writers, hemispheric traditions, literature and kindred arts, and other topics.

CRS_DESC: Practical principles for development of effective teaching within the disciplines of English, Creative Writing, and Narrative Studies. Intended for teaching assistants in English.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): English (Creative Writing), English

CRS_DESC: Thematic, theoretical, or experimental studies in British and American literatures and cultures.
Editing and publishing within the tradition of literary and cultural influences upon a wide range of authors, readers and genres.
Research and identification of internships; preparation of application materials for submission to in-person and remote internship opportunities.

CRS_NAME: Digital Publishing and Literary Writing for New Media
CRS_DESC: Discussion of literary texts combined with hands-on digital practice in composition, design and fabrication for electronic publication, including formal, technical and philosophical issues.

CRS_NAME: Publishing on Both Sides of the Transom
CRS_DESC: Editorial and publishing workshop with an intensive hands-on student project following the progress of a single piece of writing from manuscript to print.
Practical experience in the publishing world for acquiring skills and knowledge beyond the classroom.
Studies in meaning and meaning-making, form, comparative theory, theories of history and culture, theory in the classroom, and other topics.
Issues and theory of studying literature in relation to history, science, politics, psychology, religion, sociology, media, the visual arts, and other disciplines.
Studies of major and minor, canonic and non-canonic writers.
Theories of race and ethnicity, cultural imperialism, discourse of power and class, literatures of the Americas, and other topics.
Study of conventional and experimental works of creative nonfiction, from memoir to poetry, criticism and scholarship, focusing on issues of form, ethics, style and audience.
CRS_NOTE:

  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Doctoral Student

CRS_DESC: This two-credit course helps ABD students craft their professional identities and placement materials as they make the transition from graduate school to their academic position. Graded CR/NC. Not available for degree credit.

CRS_DESC: Gateway to the majors and minors in environmental studies. Provides students with an overview of how government agencies and societal institutions address (or fail to address) the interrelated social and scientific aspects of environmental problems and policies.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Exploration of the major social, political, economic, religious, and philosophical disagreements that exist between scholars, leaders, and citizens concerning today's most serious environmental issues and problems. Not available for credit to environmental studies majors and minors.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Extensive academic preparation in the physics, physiology, safety, and methodology for in-water scientific diving.
Examination of scientific, social, political, and economic factors of fisheries management, engaging students in key issues of coastal and marine sustainability.
Overview of issues related to water and soil sustainability including science, policy and business aspects. Recommended Preparation ENST-100.
Overview of issues related to water and soil sustainability including science, policy and business aspects. Recommended Preparation ENST-100.
Exploration of environmentally transmitted human diseases; understanding the human/pathogen/environment nexus that leads to disease in human populations; disease transmission reduction.
Explores issues concerning behavior of humans towards the nonhuman world. Examines a wide spectrum of ethical issues.
Introduces students to central concepts and theories in environmental law and regulation; analyzes present environmental laws and regulations.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the POSC department but may qualify for major credit in ENST. To register, enroll in POSC 347.

CRS_DESC: Survey of major environmental policies both international and domestic as they relate to fisheries, shipping, pollution, seaports and coastal management.

CRS_NAME: Economics for Natural Resources and the Environment
CRS_DESC: An introduction to the economic tools and issues that affect natural resource use and environmental management.

CRS_NAME: Directed Governmental and Political Leadership Internship
CRS_DESC: Intensive experience in governmental and political offices. Minimum time requirement; evaluation by office and intern report required.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the POSC department but may qualify for major credit in ENST. To register, enroll in POSC 395.

CRS_DESC: Should environmental issues be treated as threats to security? Survey of recent literature explores global environmental politics using a security framework. Recommended preparation: Environmental studies course work.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the IR department but may qualify for major credit in ENST. To register, enroll in IR 422.

CRS_DESC: Examination of the tools used to reconstruct past climate change and a thorough discussion of past climate changes on earth with an emphasis on the recent past.
Sustainability professionals instruct on the specifics of working in sustainability, with topics such as community engagement for sustainability or creating/operating a sustainability non-profit.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior, Senior (fifth year)

CRS_DESC: Focuses on how businesses both contribute to and can help address environmental sustainability challenges and the role of the broader political-economy in shaping that interaction.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the MOR department but may qualify for major credit in ENST. To register, enroll in MOR 466.

CRS_DESC: Field skills and management tools to investigate environmental problems in coastal zones; cultural and scientific topics; collection and analysis of environmental data.

CRS_NAME: Social Science Research Methods for Environmental Analysis
CRS_DESC: Applied social science research methods; introduces key qualitative and quantitative methods of collecting social data relevant for environmental issues.
Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.

CRS_NAME: Directed Environmental Policy and Science Internship
CRS_DESC: Provides opportunities for professional development in environmental policy and science and prepares students for career or graduate school in environmental-related fields. Students are placed in internships and guided before and during the internship period and gain practical experience and learn how government and nongovernmental organizations pursue and implement environmental policy and science work.
CRS_NOTE:
• Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Environmental Science and Health, Environmental Studies, Environmental Studies
  • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior, Senior (fifth year)

CRS_DESC: Students form multidisciplinary teams and are asked to study and resolve a major environmental problem facing a particular region or target population.
Selected topics dealing with environmental issues and problems.
Introduces students to the central issues, concepts, and theories in environmental law and policy and analyzes present environmental laws and regulations.
Analyzes various potential environmental risks and examines how science, government, and business measure and prepare for environmental risks.
Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
Major theoretical approaches to the study of war; focus is on recent issues in security studies.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Master Student

CRS_NAME: Human Impact of Genocide and Mass Violence
CRS_DESC: Analysis of the consequences of genocide and mass violence on human security and individual well-being and an exploration of processes to address mass atrocities.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following major(s): Global Security Studies

CRS_DESC: Introduction to current French. Oral practice, listening and reading comprehension; grammar necessary for simple spoken and written expression.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Students with previous experience with French are REQUIRED to take the French placement exam. D-clearance for French I is available at language.usc.edu. The date and time of the final exam for this course is Saturday, May 4 from 11am-1pm.

CRS_DESC: Continuation of 120.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (FREN 120 or MPVA 261)
  • Note: Students with previous experience with French are REQUIRED to take the French placement exam. French 150 registration requires a French 150 placement score. After the first week of classes, all sections will be converted from "R" to "D," requiring instructor approval. The date and time of the final exam for this course is Saturday, May 4 from 11am-1pm. Section 35305 is a Maymester course in Dijon, France.

CRS_NAME: Accelerated French for Speakers of Spanish and Other Romance Languages
CRS_DESC: Accelerated introduction to written and spoken French for students with a high level of proficiency in Spanish or another Romance Language. Students completing this course may enroll in the third semester of the basic language sequence FREN 220.
Continuation of FREN 150. Review of structural patterns of French; selected cultural and literary readings; conversation and composition.

Designed for non-majors/minors interested in maintaining and developing French language competency. Builds vocabulary, ease of communication, and cultural knowledge through discussion of contemporary topics. Graded Credit/No Credit. Not available for credit to French majors. Not open to French majors.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (FREN 202 or FREN 220)
  • Restriction: Registration closed to the following major(s): French

CRS_DESC: Introduction to French literature through the study of texts and audiovisuals organized around a central theme; develops close-reading techniques and discursive skills; reviews French grammar.
Study of Francophone womens narratives combined with practice of editing personal narratives. Conducted in English.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Note: This is an experiential class that requires a community engagement component. Please refer to course flyer for more information.

CRS_DESC: Grammatical structure and vocabulary building with practical application to written composition. Prerequisites: FREN 250.

CRS_NAME: Public Memory and the Ghosts of History
CRS_DESC: An exploration of cultural haunting in post-Revolutionary France, grounded in critical approaches to literature, with a focus on collective memory, loss and historical violence.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: FREN 150
  • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Maymester course in Paris, France. For further information about the course, planned programming, application process/ timeline, and other logistics, students must submit an interest form at bit.ly/GhostsParisMaymester.

CRS_DESC: Analysis of French media. Practice in sustained conversation. Emphasis on spoken sentence patterns. Prerequisites: FREN 250.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: FREN 250
  • Note: This class is a Maymester offering in Dijon, France.

CRS_DESC: Advanced composition through critical reading of literary texts; comprehensive analysis of difficult grammatical structures and stylistics. Prerequisite: FREN 300.
Specific vocabulary and formulae used in international commerce. Attention given to developing vocabulary and standard forms appropriate to individual career objectives.
Introduction to historical, thematic perspectives of French foreign policy since 1945 including review of external and internal constraints influencing foreign policy. (Paris semester only).
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the IR department but may qualify for major credit in FREN. To register, enroll in IR 368.

CRS_NAME: Equality and Difference around the Enlightenment
CRS_DESC: 18th- and 20th-century debates around the idea of equality and the notion of difference. Relevance of the Enlightenment to contemporary discussions of identity, citizenship, and human rights. Conducted in English.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Diversity: This course satisfies the university's diversity requirement.

CRS_NAME: Medicine, Health and the Body in Literature and Culture
CRS_DESC: Study of health, the body and medicine through literature and culture in comparative fashion. Taught in English.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Exploration of experimental artistic collaborations between poets, novelists,art critics and artists of the Paris Avant-gardes in 19th and 20th Century. Taught in French. Paris Semester. Prerequisite: FREN 300. Corequisite: FREN 330.
Major figures and their roles in French society and contributions to French literature. Conducted in French. Corequisite: FREN 330.
CRS_NOTE:
• Corequisite: FREN 330
  • Note: Students may take this class EITHER while also enrolled in FREN 330 in the same semester, or after having completed FREN 330.

CRS_DESC: Study and analysis of representative works and major intellectual, cultural, and artistic trends from the modern period (post-1789). Prerequisite: FREN-330.

(Paris Semester only) An analysis of the prestige of Paris, past and present, based upon close examination of literary texts and graphic materials, and visits to sites and monuments. Recommended preparation: FREN 300
Selected topics such as the press, educational institutions, French cinema today, and French colonial history. Conducted in French. Prerequisites: FREN 330.
Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_DESC: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
A seven-to-eleven week course offered for incoming freshmen; limited to 18 students. Graded CR/NC. A combined maximum of 4 units of FSEM 100 and FSEM 101 may be applied to the degree.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Freshmen

CRS_DESC: Geologic structure and evolution of planet earth. Principles ofplate tectonics, rocks and minerals, processes of mountainbuilding, continent and ocean formation, earthquakes, volcanism,development of landforms by running water and glaciers. Lecture, 3hours; laboratory, 2 hours. One all-day or two-day field triprequired.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: Physical, chemical, and geological character of the oceans andocean basins. Origin of the oceans. Ocean processes and agents.Economic value of the oceans. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 2 hours. One all-day field trip required.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: Impact of civilization on planet earth, and impact of earth's natural evolution on society: earthquakes, volcanism, landslides, floods, global warming, acid rain, groundwater depletion and pollution; mineral and fossil fuel depletion, formation of the ozone hole. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 2 hours. One all-day or overnight field trip.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

CRS_NAME: The History of Life on Earth
CRS_DESC: Topically-driven exploration of evolution, environmental change, and the history of life on Earth via the fossil record with the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles as a laboratory. How the changing Earth and life co-evolved through time.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

CRS_DESC: Energy resources from a global perspective, including fossil fuels, nuclear, and renewable energy.

CRS_DESC: Laboratory component for GEOL 105Lg, 107Lxg, 108Lg, 125Lxg, 130Lxg, 150Lxg, or 240Lxg for students with equivalent lecture credit from another institution.

Principles of geology with emphasis on structural geology, hydrogeology and geologic hazards; basic geologic considerations in civil engineering practice; introduction to mineralogy and petrology. Field trip required. Lecture, 3 hours; laboratory, 2 hours. Duplicates credit in GEOL 105Lg and 108Lg.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for lecture and one lab

  • Note: Register for lecture and lab

CRS_DESC: Introduction to scientific inquiry, field research opportunities, and history of physical sciences; strategies, research methodologies, and writing skills for proposals, abstracts, papers, and professional development. Duplicates credit in the former GEOL-385. Recommended preparation: A GE course in Earth Science.

Plate tectonics, magnetic and gravity fields, earthquakes, seismic waves, reflection and regraction seismics, heat transport, mantle convection, deep Earth structure, data analysis. Includes field trip.

• Prerequisite: MATH 126
  • Corequisite: 1 from (PHYS 135B or PHYS 152)
  • Note: Register for lecture and lab

CRS_DESC: Examination of the tools used to reconstruct past climate change and a thorough discussion of past climate changes on earth with an emphasis on the recent past.

• Prerequisite: CHEM 105b and MATH 126
  • Note: Register for lecture and lab

Special topics in the earth sciences. Field trip required when appropriate to the topic. Departmental approval required.

Mesozoic and Cenozoic paleoceanography; analytical approaches applied to water mass history, paleocirculation, paleoproductivity, nutrient cycling, and paleotemperature reconstruction. Lecture, readings, and research project. Recommended preparation: GEOL 412 or GEOL 512 and GEOL 460L.

Includes review of plate tectonics, seismology, geodesy, paleomagnetism, geodynamics, Quaternary dating techniques, tectonic geomorphology, paleoseismology, and seismic hazard assessment. Two weekend field trips required. Recommended preparation: GEOL 530, GEOL 531

CRS_DESC: Continuation of German I. Introduction to German culture. Prerequisite: 101.
Intermediate German. Increasing emphasis on listening and speaking skills and a review of basic structures of German. Discussion of cultural aspects. Prerequisite: 101 and 102.
Conversational German in a variety of topical settings and vocabulary domains. Prerequisite: 3rd semester German or equivalent.

  • Note: After the first week of classes, all sections will be converted from "R" to "D", requiring instructor approval. The date and time of the final exam for this course is Saturday, May 4 from 11am - 1pm. PLEASE NOTE: SECTION #34457 IS A MAYMESTER COURSE IN ROME, ITALY.

CRS_DESC: Combined classroom discussion and supervised internship at companies. Practical experience in applying communication and cultural knowledge in a professional employment context.

Continuation of Italian III. Review and expand upon abilities to create with the language in concrete exchanges, descriptions, comparisons, questions and discussions relevant to current issues and topics.
An interdisciplinary introduction to the literary, artistic, and political movements which contributed to the shaping of modern Italy. Taught in English.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Reading and close textual scrutiny of major short stories from Boccaccio's Decameron to the present. Conducted in English. (Duplicates credit in former ITAL 462)
Analysis of the Divina Commedia and other works. Conducted in English. (Duplicates credit in former ITAL 450)
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Italian dramatic literature from the earliest written documents to the present. Reading and close textual scrutiny of plays by major dramatists from the Renaissance to the present. Taught in Italian.
Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_DESC: Major ideas, personalities, and movements in Jewish history from antiquity to the present in light of the interaction of the Jews with the general culture.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_DESC: Exploring the Hebrew Bible, the world in which it arose, and influential texts, including work from Ancient Egypt, Mesopotamia and the Southern Levant.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Jewish beliefs, practices, and history from the biblical period to the present; Judaic contributions to Western civilization.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Historical background and responses to the Holocaust, withspecial emphasis on ethical implications.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Investigates contemporary conflicts in the discovery of the ancient world. Students will ask essential questions about the power of discovering and showcasing specific narratives.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Examine the history of race and racialization in Jewish life, culture and history across the world and the impact of race on Jewish tradition.
Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_DESC: Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
Essentials of Latin grammar and vocabulary.
Essentials of Latin grammar and vocabulary, continued. Basic reading skills.
Reading Latin literature. Introduction to reading and translation of classical Latin prose and poetry. Extensive grammar review.

Discourse patterns among diverse social groups in institutional and interpersonal settings; interrelationships among language practices and gender, socioeconomic status, ethnicity; social structures and cultural values as reflected in language policies and practices.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_DESC: Empirical study of the sounds and structures of human language;syntax and semantics; language change; linguistic universals.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Study of human linguistic competence and technologies that simulate it. Phonetics, vibration and signal processing, speech recognition, neural networks.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and lab

CRS_DESC: A survey of topics in phonology and morphology.
Experimental and theoretical aspects of how spoken and written language is produced and understood, learned during childhood, and affected by brain damage.
Familiarization with the articulation and transcription of speech sounds. Also vocal tract anatomy, acoustics, speech technology, non-English sounds, perception. Includes laboratory exercises.
Elicitation techniques and methodological principles; recording and analysis of phonological, syntactic and semantic structures; practical approaches to procedures used in urban and rural settings.
Introduction to speech synthesis and speech recognition technologies from both a phonetics point of view and a computational point of view.
Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_DESC: Writing of the honors thesis. Registration is restricted to honors students.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration closed to the following major(s): Linguistics

CRS_DESC: Traditional views of phonology; generative phonology; current developments in phonological research and theory.
Principles and comparison of modern theories of grammar with special reference to syntax.
Intensive work in semantic theory, in preparation for a research specialization in the area.

Source-filter theory, acoustic corrrelates of speech sounds, vocal tract and auditory physiology, coarticulation and motor coordination, speech technology including synthesis and recognition, experimental design and statistics, and speech perception.
Current issues in psycholinguistic theory.
Research leading to the master's degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
Credit on acceptance of thesis.
Credit on acceptance of thesis.
Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department.

CRS_NAME: Seminar in Experimental Methods in Linguistics
CRS_DESC: Topics in quantitataive methods in linguistics research, e.g., covariance structure analysis, multi-dimensional scaling, log linear model, meta-analysis.
Research leading to the doctorate. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.

CRS_DESC: Review of Algebra. Real numbers, linear equations and inequalities, functions, graphs, systems of equations, exponents, polynomials, factoring, rational expressions, radicals, quadratic equations and solutions. Graded CR/NC.
Equations and inequalities; functions; graphs; polynomial and rational functions; exponential, logarithmic, and trigonometric function; analytic geometry.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: MATH 040
  • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_DESC: An introduction to the basic tools of statistics. Descriptive statistics; probability; expected value; normal approximation sampling; chance models; tests of significance. Recommended preparation: MATH 040x or math placement exam. Not available for major credit to Math students.
CRS_NOTE:
• General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_NAME: Introduction to Mathematics for Business and Economics
CRS_DESC: Functions, graphs, polynomial and rational functions, exponential and logarithmic functions, matrices, systems of linear equations.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: MATH 040
  • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_DESC: Limits; continuity, derivatives and applications; antiderivatives; the fundamental theorem of calculus; exponential and logarithmic functions.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: MATH 108
  • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_DESC: A continuation of MATH 125: trigonometric functions; applications of integration; techniques of integration; indeterminate forms; infinite series; Taylor series; polar coordinates.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: MATH 125
  • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_NAME: Calculus II for Engineers and Scientists
CRS_DESC: Trigonometric functions; applications of integration; techniques of integration; indeterminate forms; infinite series; Taylor series; polar coordinates. Engineering and physics applications. Prerequisite: MATH 125. (Duplicates credit in MATH 126 and MATH 127)
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: MATH 125
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_DESC: Descriptive statistics, probability, discrete and continuous random variables, expectation and variance, sampling, Central Limit Theorem, estimation, hypothesis testing, correlation and regression. Emphasis on health science. Prerequisite: MATH 118xg or MATH 125.

CRS_NAME: Linear Algebra and Linear Differential Equations
CRS_DESC: Matrices, systems of linear equations, vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues, systems of linear differential equations.
Vectors, vector valued functions; differential and integral calculus of functions of several variables; Green's theorem, Divergence theorem, Stoke's theorem.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (MATH 126 or MATH 127 or MATH 129)
  • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_NAME: Calculus III for Engineers and Scientists
CRS_DESC: A continuation of 129; vectors, vector valued functions; differential and integral calculus of functions of several variables; Greens theorem. Engineering and physics applications. Prerequisite: MATH 126, or MATH 127, or MATH 129.(Duplicates credit in MATH 226 and MATH 227)
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (MATH 126 or MATH 127 or MATH 129)
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_NAME: Mathematics of Physics and Engineering I
CRS_DESC: First-order differential equations; second-order linear differential equations; determinants and matrices; systems of linear differential equations; Laplace transforms.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (MATH 226 or MATH 227 or MATH 229)
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_DESC: Preparation for reading and writing proofs with applications from major branches of mathematics, focusing on axiomatic structures and transformations that preserve structure.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (MATH 126 or MATH 127 or MATH 129)
  • Note: Register for lecture and discussion

CRS_NAME: Statistical Inference and Data Analysis II
CRS_DESC: Confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, p-values, likelihood ratio, nonparametrics, descriptive statistics, regression, multiple linear regression, experimental design, analysis of variance, categorical data, chi-squared tests, Bayesian statistics.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: MATH 307
  • Note: Register for lecture and discussion

CRS_DESC: Systematic approach to solving non-standard and competition level math problems on inequalities, infinite sums and products, combinatorics, number theory and games.

Principles for testing hypotheses and estimation, confidence intervals, methods of moments, maximum likelihood, information inequality, likelihood ratio tests, goodness of fit and nonparametric methods.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: MATH 407
  • Note: Register for one lecture and one discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_DESC: Sets; relations; groups; homomorphisms; symmetric groups; Abelian groups; Sylow's theorems; introduction to rings and fields.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (MATH 290 or MATH 430 or MATH 432)
  • Note: Register for lecture and discussion

CRS_DESC: The real number system, metric spaces, limits, continuity, derivatives and integrals, infinite series.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (MATH 290 or MATH 430 or MATH 432)
  • Note: Register for one lecture and discussion listed immediately following that lecture

CRS_DESC: Implicit function theorems, Jacobians, transformations, multiple integrals, line integrals.
Introduction to the theory of numbers, including prime factorization, congruences, primitive roots, N-th power residues, number theoretic functions and certain diophantine equations.

Mathematical induction, counting principles, arrangements, selections, binomial coefficients, generating functions, recurrence relations, inclusion-exclusion, symmetric groups, graphs, Euler and Hamiltonian circuits, trees, graph algorithms; applications.

CRS_NAME: Mathematics of Physics and Engineering II
CRS_DESC: Vector field theory; theorems of Gauss, Green, and Stokes; Fourier series and integrals; complex variables; linear partial differential equations; series solutions of ordinary differential equations.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (MATH 245 or (MATH 225 and MATH 226) or (MATH 225 and MATH 227) or (MATH 225 and MATH 229))
CRS_NOTE: • Prerequisite: 1 from (MATH 245 or (MATH 225 and MATH 226) or (MATH 225 and MATH 227) or (MATH 225 and MATH 229))

CRS_DESC: Evolution of mathematical ideas and techniques as seen through a study of the contributions of eminent mathematicians to the formulation and solution of celebrated problems. Recommended preparation: upper division MATH course.

Rounding errors in digital computation; solution of linear algebraic systems; Newton's method for nonlinear systems; matrix eigenvalues; polynomial approximation; numerical integration; numerical solution of ordinary differential equations.

Formulation and study of models arising in population dynamics, growth of plankton, pollution of rivers, highway traffic, morphogenesis and tidal dynamics: stability, oscillations, bifurcations, chaos. The lab will consist of computer simulation of models using commercially available software.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: 1 from (MATH 225 or MATH 245)
  • Note: Register for lecture and discussion

CRS_NAME: Theory and Computational Methods for Optimization
CRS_DESC: Methods for static, dynamic, unconstrained, constrained optimization. Gradient, conjugate gradient, penalty methods. Lagrange multipliers, least squares, linear, nonlinear dynamic programming. Application to control and estimation.
CRS_PREREQ: Prerequisite: (MATH 226 or MATH 227 or MATH 229) and (MATH 225 or MATH 245)
CRS_NOTE: • Prerequisite: 1 from (MATH 226 or MATH 227 or MATH 229) and 1 from (MATH 225 or MATH 245)

CRS_DESC: Polynomial rings, vector spaces, linear transformations, canonical forms, inner product spaces.

CRS_NAME: Introduction to Theory of Complex Variables
CRS_DESC: Complex numbers and functions. Power series, analytic functions, harmonic functions. Complex integration, Cauchy's theorem, Cauchy's formula. Conformal mapping. Applications in physics and engineering.
Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
CRS_NOTE: • Restriction: Registration open to the following class level(s): Junior, Senior

CRS_DESC: Lectures directed to mathematics graduate students by faculty of the department and by outside speakers. Problem solving workshops. Graded CR/NC.

Linear equations and matrices, Gauss elimination, error estimates, iteration techniques; contractive mappings, Newton's method; matrix eigenvalue problems; least-squares approximation, Newton-Cotes and Gaussian quadratures; finite difference methods. Prerequisite: linear algebra and calculus.
Computational linear algebra; solution of general nonlinear systems of equations; approximation theory using functional analysis; numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations.
Markov processes in discrete or continuous time; renewal processes; martingales; brownian motion and diffusion theory; random walks, inventory models, population growth, queuing models, shot noise.

a: Probability spaces; distributions and characteristic functions; laws of large numbers, central limit problems; stable and infinitely divisible laws; conditional distributions. Prerequisite: 525a or 570. b: Dependence, martingales, ergodic theorems, second-order random functions, harmonic analysis, Markov processes.

B: Commutative Algebra: Integrality, Hilbert Basis theorem, Hilbert Nullstellensatz; Modules: modules over PID's, chain conditions, tensor products; Noncommutative Rings: Jacobson radical, Artin-Wedderburn theorem, Maschke's theorem.
Major parametric and non-parametric statistical tools used in biomedical research, computer packages including SAS. Includes laboratory. Lecture, 2 hours; laboratory, 2 hours.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: PM 510
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the PM department but may qualify for major credit in MATH. To register, enroll in PM 511a.

CRS_DESC: Statistical methods for analysis of categorical data including dichotomous, ordinal, multinomial and count data, using Stata package. Includes laboratory.
CRS_NOTE:
• Prerequisite: PM 511A
  • Crosslist: This course is offered by the PM department but may qualify for major credit in MATH. To register, enroll in PM 511b.

CRS_DESC: Experimental laboratory trading for financial markets using double auctions: handling statistical packages for data analysis. Practical training in virtual market environments, using financial trading system software.
CRS_NOTE: • Note: Register for lecture and one discussion

CRS_DESC: Theory of analytic functions--power series and integral representations, calculus of residues, harmonic functions, normal families, approximation theorems, conformal mapping, analytical continuation.

a: Measure and integration over abstract measure spaces, Radon-Nikodym theorem, Fubini's theorem, convergence theorems, differentiation. Prerequisite: 425ab. b: Metric spaces, contraction principle, category, Banach spaces, Riesz representation theorem, properties of Lp, Hilbert spaces, orthogonal expansions, Fourier series and transforms, convolutions. Prerequisite: 525a.

Advanced topics in stochastic analysis, asset pricing in continuous time, stochastic control, Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equations, incomplete markets, American options, exotic options, term structure of interest rates. Duplicates credit in the former MATH-506.

Combinatorics motivated by Representation Theory and Algebraic Geometry. Topics may include: representations of the symmetric group, symmetric functions, Young tableaux and plane partitions, permutation enumeration.

Elementary theory of manifolds, Lie groups, homogeneous spaces, fiber bundles and connections. Riemannian manifolds, curvature and conjugate points, second fundamental form, other topics. Prerequisite: 440.

Parametric families of distributions, sufficiency. Estimation: methods of moments, maximum likelihood, unbiased estimation. Comparison of estimators, optimality, information inequality, asymptotic efficiency. EM algorithm, jacknife and bootstrap.
Transfer function models; stationary, nonstationary processes; moving average, autoregressive models; spectral analysis; estimation of mean, autocorrelation, spectrum; seasonal time series.
Second-order partial differential equations of elliptic, parabolic, and hyperbolic type; in particular, potential and wave equations.

Existence, uniqueness and continuation of solutions, differential inequalities, linear systems, Sturm-Liouville theory, boundary value problems, Poincare-Bendixson theory, periodic solutions, perturbations, stability, fixed point techniques.

Study of a single leader or small set of leaders, including the strengths and weaknesses that distinguish them and the cultural forces that nurture them.

CRS_DESC: A multidisciplinary exploration of the Armenian cultural heritage through the ages -- folklore, traditions, religious practices, literature, architecture, painting, sculpture, music, theater, film and dance.
Introduction to the cultural origins, history, art, literature, and films of South Asia, comprising Afghanistan, Bangladesh, India, the Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka.
Explores the modern Middle East by focusing on the process of globalization.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: History and culture of modern Iran from the nineteenth century to present through historical and ethnographic approaches to Iran today, richly contextualizing events and people.

CRS_NAME: Politics of Film and Literature in Modern Iran
CRS_DESC: Explores contemporary Iranian society through the study of social tensions created by poverty-wealth, tradition-modernity, masculinity-femininity, and notions of religio-political authority as reflected in the literature and films of the country.
CRS_NOTE: • General Education: This course satisfies the university's general education requirement.

CRS_DESC: Introduction to problems and issues in the Middle East today: religio-ethnic rivalries, conflicting nationalisms and ideologies, the Arab-Israeli conflict, Middle East oil.
CRS_NOTE: • Crosslist: This course is offered by the IR department but may qualify for major credit in MDES. To register, enroll in IR 362.

CRS_DESC: Social, cultural, and political history of Egypt from Alexander to Cleopatra; state formation; immigration and cultural interaction between ethnic groups.
